fullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-christmas-carol-review-a-cold-weather-favorite-loses-its-chills-11575576189

ShareResizeCampbell Scott as Ebenezer Scrooge in ‘A Christmas Carol’ Joan MarcusNew York

Stage versions of “A Christmas Carol” have yet to become a theatrical equivalent of the ever-popular “Nutcrackers” that serve as perpetually milkable cash cows for America’s ballet companies. Even so, there are plenty of them, some of which are quite good, and I’ve never understood why Patrick Stewart’s one-man version of Charles Dickens’s seasonal tale of spiritual redemption, which has had four Broadway runs since 1991, is the only one to have had any luck there.
dtliExcerpt: This handsome new staging of 'A Christmas Carol' at the Lyceum Theatre offers a respectable if not revelatory take on the Dickens classic, with Campbell Scott bringing a welcome subtlety to Scrooge.
showScoreExcerpt: This handsome new staging of 'A Christmas Carol' at the Lyceum Theatre offers a respectable if not revelatory take on the Dickens classic, with Campbell Scott bringing a welcome subtlety to Scrooge.

keyPhrases.quote: This handsome new staging offers a respectable if not revelatory take on the Dickens classic.

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 4 models agree: Positive | Claude: The review uses positive language ('handsome', 'respectable', 'welcome subtlety') but explicitly states it's 'not revelatory', indicating a qualified positive recommendation without strong enthusiasm. | GPT-4o: The review describes the production as 'respectable' and praises Campbell Scott's performance, indicating a positive but not overly enthusiastic recommendation. | Gemini: The review uses the word "respectable" which indicates a positive but not overwhelmingly enthusiastic recommendation. The phrase "if not revelatory" suggests reservations. | Kimi: The critic offers qualified praise for the handsome staging and Scott's subtle performance, but the caveat that it is 'not revelatory' keeps it in the lower range of positive recommendations.
